attributes.comment:
Increasing the USCIS costs for adoption applications by an average of 66% is
unjustifiable and places an undue burden on applicants.

A USCIS document fee update was done in 2005, less than 2 years ago. If all the
additional costs that have been recently identified, and are the basis for the current
fee increase, did not exist in 2005, it does not appear that an effective cost-benefit
analysis was done before starting any new procedures, new requirements, or
expanding existing services between 2005 and the present. If these additional
costs existed in 2005, why weren't they addressed then?

In the Dept of Homeland Security Document 8 CFR Part 103, it is stated that the
fee increase will be used to enhance services that range from increasing staff to
technology investments to infrastructure improvement. Fees will continue to be
used to recover costs to services for non-paying users. This sounds great;
however, the problem in always in the details. Why isn't there sufficient workforce
to meet workload demands? Is the solution to simply hire more people, at a huge
cost, or make the current workforce more productive? Why is "making a
determination" so extremely expensive? (Table 10) How can this cost be reduced?
Why is "complexity" so expensive? Is it in part due to organizational dysfunction
which makes completing a dossier a chaotic procedure with one office not
communicating with another? All I see are macro level discussions of agency
performance, but we all know that it is not only the system, but the parts and how
they work together that makes a big impact on performance. I don't see much
desire in the document to improve efficiency and effectiveness. Rather, I see
justification for rising costs.

Was there a cost-benefit analysis done before security, as it is currently defined,
was made a priority for the USCIS and the how this would be funded. It appears
not, because according to the document, a $1 billion funding gap now exists.
Before a massive increase in biometric requirements or background checks was
identified as necessary for security, who figured out the costs? "Certain
immigration benefit determinations have become more complex....with new
programs and eligibilities." Ok, this makes sense, but who pays for it? Why
should the lack of analyses and planning for this be passed on now to adoption
applicants, when they already pay taxes?

Obviously a reduction in services is not desirable and reducing backlog is very
important to both the United States Government (USG) and USCIS clients/users.
Hiring new staff and using electronic solutions are effective solutions to improved
services and increased security. However, raising international adoption fees by
over 60% is not the solution to paying for it. Those families who are adopting are
already making huge sacrifices to adopt; it is very expensive, the administrative
procedures are a nightmare, and the whole process carries a huge emotional
investment which sometimes does not end happily. They are creating families and
need all kinds of support for that; they do not need increased expenses to what is
already, on average, $20,000.

The USG has to juggle many priorities. If homeland security is so important to the
Administration, and USCIS has a role to play in that, then the USG needs to make
budget decisions in line with that priority. It appears that this is not the case with
USCIS with the $1 billion budget gap.

The private sector can pass on its costs to the consumer who makes the choice
to purchase a good or service. The public sector cannot operate on the exact
same principal as it results in a burden on individual users, who have no other
choice. Adoption applicants and well as all other users of USCIS forms have no
choice in the matter. Cost recovery is a good tool, not a guiding principal.

US Citizens pay taxes and it is the responsibility of the USG, no matter what
administration is in office, to analyze and decide upon the most efficient and
equitable use and redistribution of those resources. If the IEFA needs more funds
to operate, then the Administration needs to allocate more funds so that it can
meet the needs of USCIS customers, performance standards, and its institutional
goal of increasing national security. Without being sarcastic, the amount spent
monthly in Iraq and Afghanistan and Israel and Egypt and on other foreign policy
goals is hindering the proper functioning of the USG on its own soil. Budgets are
finite; income is finite, and expenses need to be finite, also. Where are the USG?s
priorities?

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Kathryn M. Lane
